snippet: In the days since an unarmed man was killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., the selective release of information, and especially the anonymity granted the officer, has stoked frustrations.
abstract: Selective release of information about police shooting of unarmed teenager Michael Brown is stoking frustrations in the largely African-American community of Ferguson, Mo, where residents describe increasingly tense relations with police; Police Chief Thomas Jackson refuses to release the officer's name or details of the investigation, including how many times Brown had been shot, spurring continued protests.

byline.original: By JULIE BOSMAN and ERIK ECKHOLM
byline.contributor: Julie Bosman reported from Ferguson, and Erik Eckholm from New York. Reporting was contributed by Timothy Williams, Joseph Goldstein and Serge F. Kovaleski from New York, and John Schwartz from St. Louis.

lead_paragraph: In the days since an unarmed man was killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., the selective release of information, and especially the anonymity granted the officer, has stoked frustrations.

headline.main: Anonymity in Police Shooting Fuels Anger in Missouri
headline.print_headline: Anonymity in Police Shooting Fuels Frustration
